Commonwealth v. McDonough, 370 Mass. 1 (.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
Commonwealth v. McDonough, 370 Mass. 1 (.case_name: Keough v. Director of the Division of Employment Security
Commonwealth v. McDonough, 370 Mass. 1 (.support_reasoning: The case is an unemployment compensation/administrative law decision about statutory eligibility for benefits and the meaning of “available for work,” not a tort or landowner-liability case. It does not discuss negligence elements such as duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, or damages, nor does it apply Massachusetts tort principles or Restatement provisions in that context. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition asserted about negligence and landowner liability.
Commonwealth v. McDonough, 370 Mass. 1 (.relevant_excerpt: “Unemployment compensation is not a social welfare program based on need but is specifically directed toward a class of unemployed persons who have been and continue to be attached to the labor force. ‘Unemployment benefits are not for those who are incapable of working.’… Under this type of program, availability for work is clearly a valid condition on eligibility for benefits, and the classification of a person unable to transport herself to employment opportunities as ‘unavailable for work’ cannot be considered arbitrary, irrational, or an invidious discrimination.”

O\u2019Connor v. United States, 406 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
O\u2019Connor v. United States, 406 Mass.case_name: Sharpe v. Springfield Bus Terminal Corp.
O\u2019Connor v. United States, 406 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with the proper statutory rate and calculation of prejudgment and postjudgment interest in a wrongful death and conscious suffering judgment. It does not discuss or analyze negligence elements such as duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, or landowner liability standards. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the negligence and landowner duty principles for which it is being cited.
O\u2019Connor v. United States, 406 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
The issue in the present appeal is what is the appropriate rate of prejudgment and postjudgment interest.
...
We turn to the question of postjudgment interest. Postjudgment interest is governed by G. L. c. 235, § 8 (1988 ed.). Section 8 provides that “Every judgment for the payment of money shall bear interest from the day of its entry at the same rate per annum as provided for prejudgment interest in such award, report, verdict or finding.” In this case, that rate is 6%.

MacDougall v. Kelley, 317 Mass. 195 (194.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
MacDougall v. Kelley, 317 Mass. 195 (194.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns probate law and the removal of an executrix as “unsuitable,” and discusses the Probate Court’s inherent and statutory powers, not negligence, duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, damages, or landowner premises liability. Nothing in the reasoning addresses tort elements or landowner obligations to entrants, so it does not support the proposition cited. The case is therefore inapposite as authority for general negligence or landowner liability principles.
MacDougall v. Kelley, 317 Mass. 195 (194.relevant_excerpt:
“General Laws (Ter. Ed.) c. 195, §11, empowers a Probate Court to remove an executor or administrator for a number of reasons, one of which is that he is ‘unsuitable’ for the trust…

The statutory word ‘unsuitable’ gives wide discretion to a probate judge. Past maladministration of a comparable trust, bad character, misconduct, neglect of duty, or physical or mental incapacity, warrants a finding that an executor or administrator is unsuitable… Actual dereliction in duty need not be shown.”

Giovanniello v. Newburyport, 394 Mass. 5.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
Giovanniello v. Newburyport, 394 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The quoted passage from Giovanniello v. Newburyport concerns criminal law and the relevance of voluntary intoxication to specific intent crimes. It does not address civil negligence, elements of duty, foreseeability, breach, causation, damages, or landowner liability. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the tort-law duty of care principles for which it is being cited.
Giovanniello v. Newburyport, 394 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: "In the instant case, I read the opinion of the court as making the voluntary ingestion of intoxicants relevant to the ‘specific intent’ required for the crime of assault with intent to murder, just as we have made it relevant to the ‘deliberate premeditation’ required for certain cases of murder in the first degree."

Bartell v. Geagan, 363 Mass. 733 (1973).proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
Bartell v. Geagan, 363 Mass. 733 (1973).case_name: Ryan v. Superintendent of Schools of Quincy
Bartell v. Geagan, 363 Mass. 733 (1973).support_reasoning: The case is about teacher tenure rights and the statutory framework governing public school employment, not negligence, tort duty, foreseeability, breach, causation, damages, or landowner liability. It interprets Massachusetts education statutes (G.L. c. 71) and procedural rules for appeals, with no discussion of general tort principles or premises liability. Therefore it does not provide authority for the negligence and landowner duty-of-care proposition described.
Bartell v. Geagan, 363 Mass. 733 (1973).relevant_excerpt: “In Paquette v. Fall River, 278 Mass. 172, 173-174, we said that the various sections of G. L. c. 71, relating to the employment of public school teachers ‘indicate the purpose of the General Court to cover the field of relations between teachers and school committees and not to leave operative general rules arising from implication which would govern the rights between independent parties,’ and we further said that the provisions of § 41 giving tenure to a teacher… ‘are mandatory.’”

Grogan v. Boston Edison Co., 310 Mass. 1.raw_text: Grogan v. Boston Edison Co., 310 Mass. 196 (1941)
Grogan v. Boston Edison Co., 310 Mass. 1.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
Grogan v. Boston Edison Co., 310 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The case is a workers’ compensation decision about whether an employee’s injury “arose out of and in the course of his employment,” focusing on compensability, the scope of employment, and procedural issues about recommittal after rescript. It does not analyze common-law negligence elements (duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, damages) or landowner liability standards, nor does it apply Restatement negligence principles. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the general negligence and landowner duty propositions for which it is cited.
Grogan v. Boston Edison Co., 310 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “In order that an injured employee be entitled to compensation under the workmen’s compensation act it is not necessary that at the time of his injury he should be actively performing the duties of his employment. … There was here evidence which, if believed, warranted the findings that at the time of his injury the employee was making a permitted use of the stairway and was on his way immediately to resume his work. A conclusion was warranted that the employee received an injury arising out of and in the course of his employment.”

DeRose v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 3.raw_text: DeRose v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 347 Mass. 665 (1964)
DeRose v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 3.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
DeRose v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 3.case_name: Saxon Theatre Corp. of Boston v. Sage
DeRose v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 3.support_reasoning: The case is a contract/deceit decision about the unenforceability of an indefinite agreement and the nonactionability of certain misrepresentations of future intent. It does not address negligence, duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, damages, or landowner premises liability. Citing this opinion for general Massachusetts negligence or landowner duty principles would be inaccurate and out of context.
DeRose v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 3.relevant_excerpt: “The third and fourth counts of the plaintiff’s amended declaration do not make out a case in deceit. Because of the nature of the alleged false representations set forth in the declaration, any reliance on them would not be reasonable. The representations were: an intention ‘to construct a theatre ... [and] to lease [it] to the plaintiff, to be operated by the plaintiff under a long-term lease,’ and to ‘perform the agreement for a lease.’ Neither of these allegations can provide the basis for a reasonable reliance on successfully working out a long term lease where so much was left for future negotiations.”

Bruneau v. City of Boston, 388 Mass. 18.raw_text: Bruneau v. City of Boston, 388 Mass. 18 (1983)
Bruneau v. City of Boston, 388 Mass. 18.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
Bruneau v. City of Boston, 388 Mass. 18.case_name: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross
Bruneau v. City of Boston, 388 Mass. 18.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a private college’s authority to discipline and expel a student, focusing on arbitrariness, contractual rights, and a release of claims. It does not analyze negligence, duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, damages, or landowner premises liability, nor does it interpret statutes or Restatement provisions on those topics. Therefore, it does not support the proposition relating to Massachusetts negligence and landowner liability principles.
Bruneau v. City of Boston, 388 Mass. 18.relevant_excerpt: “We dispose of this case on the ground that the college did not violate any contractual or other rights of the plaintiffs by expelling Coveney, and on the additional ground that Coveney waived the claims he asserts here by executing a valid and binding general release. A private university, college, or school may not arbitrarily or capriciously dismiss a student… If school officials act in good faith and on reasonable grounds, however, their decision to suspend or expel a student will not be subject to successful challenge in the courts.”

Searles v. Bay State Harness Shop, 34 Ma.raw_text: Searles v. Bay State Harness Shop, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 329 (1993)
Searles v. Bay State Harness Shop, 34 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
Searles v. Bay State Harness Shop, 34 Ma.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal appeal involving suppression issues, reasonable suspicion, Terry stops, probable cause, and joint venture liability for armed robbery. It does not involve civil negligence, duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, damages, or landowner premises liability. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for Massachusetts tort law principles on negligence or landowner liability, and using it for that proposition would be inaccurate.
Searles v. Bay State Harness Shop, 34 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant appeals from his conviction, by a jury in the Superior Court, of armed robbery... The defendant’s principal claim of error is that the jewelry and weapons found at the place of arrest and the identifications of Barone and Tibaudo should have been suppressed as the fruits of an unlawful arrest made without probable cause... In deciding whether the actions of the police exceed the scope of an investigative stop, the pertinent inquiry is whether the degree of intrusion is reasonable under the circumstances."

Rossi v. Norton, 352 Mass. 318 (1967).proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following statutes, Restatement provisions, and Massachusetts tort law authorities illustrating the duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, and damages in negligence and landowner liability cases (non-exhaustive):
Rossi v. Norton, 352 Mass. 318 (1967).support_reasoning: The case is a criminal appeal involving murder, armed robbery, confessions, voluntariness, and joint enterprise liability. It does not involve negligence, landowner liability, or civil tort concepts such as duty of care, foreseeability, breach, causation, or damages. Therefore it does not provide authority for the tort-law proposition for which it is cited.
Rossi v. Norton, 352 Mass. 318 (1967).relevant_excerpt: There was no error in leaving to the jury the question whether Graves was guilty of murder in the first degree (assignment 4). It is conceded in Graves’ brief that he was engaged with Johnson in the joint enterprise to commit armed robbery, that Graves drove the getaway car from the scene of the robbery to the point where Officer O’Leary, while in fresh pursuit of Johnson, was killed.
